abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Road Network Improvement
            Project for Vietnam were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately unsatisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            substantial; Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory;
            and borrower performance was also moderately unsatisfactory.
            Some lessons learned includes: expectations of project
            outcomes need to be tempered with realistic assessments of
            what can be achieved within a single intervention.
            Introducing new systems, such as a road asset management
            system, requires a major program of change within a road
            agency. Where these changes span new technical systems,
            functional roles and responsibilities, and multiple
            stakeholder agencies there is a need to ensure that such
            reforms are introduced at a pace that they can be absorbed
            and accepted. Fundamental aspect of a functioning road
            management system is having both the technical capacity and
            financial resources to ensure regular and reliable data
            collection for monitoring and evaluating performance.
            Long-term strategic planning provides an important platform
            for communicating a sectoral vision to stakeholders. Going
            forward, the Ministry of Transport can build on this
            approach by updating the ten year strategy for road
            maintenance to address future institutional and policy
            goals, defining the role of small and medium enterprises in
            the maintenance sector, and setting and measuring network
            performance targets and fiscal projections, all of which can
            contribute to better sector governance and facilitate donor
            engagement. Capacity development for land acquisition and
            resettlement remain paramount for improving implementation
            performance. Both Vietnam and the Bank must intensify their
            efforts to refining country systems for land acquisition and
            resettlement. The Bank task team should also be proactive in
            advising relevant government officials on appropriate
            solutions to meeting Bank safeguard requirements,
            particularly where complex local conditions make policy
            compliance difficult to achieve. The existing project
            management unit structure misses opportunities to mainstream
            roles and responsibilities into relevant Ministerial
            departments. Various governance challenges exist within this
            organizational structure and may actually present an
            obstacle to improving public sector performance in
            infrastructure service delivery.

repnme.cdata!:
Vietnam - Road Network Improvement Project
            : resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Road Network Improvement Project
            (RNIP) for Vietnam will focus on the rehabilitation, and
            strategic widening of roadways, in the Northern provinces in
            Vietnam, thus reducing road transit times and
            vehicle-operating costs, while improving road access to
            poor, isolated agricultural communities, and facilitating
            agricultural production marketing. This resettlement action
            plan (RAP) provides the policy framework for compensation,
            resettlement and rehabilitation of displaced persons, as a
            result of project implementation, in compliance with the
            country's legal and regulatory policies, and the
            Bank's guidelines on resettlement. It is presented in 4
            volumes: the Umbrella Report (V. 1) which provides the
            general guidelines; RAP National Highway NH 37 (V. 2); RAP
            National Highway NH 47 (V. 3); and, RAP National Highway NH
            48 outlining the policy framework for each specific road
            segment. Compensation payments will be awarded at
            replacement costs, while land for land arrangements will be
            made, unless replacement land is unavailable, or, at the
            informed request of the displaced person (DP), cash
            compensation may be provided. Different subsidy allowances
            and other forms of assistance are also available to
            different categories of DP. Severely affected DP will be
            entitled to food aid, and/or training and income restoration
            programs, available through the District Agricultural
            Extension Office, and other relevant offices. Public
            consultation should enhance an active participation in the
            planning, and implementation of the RAP, being the
            responsibility of the project management unit to implement a
            public information campaign. Grievance mechanisms should be
            addressed beginning with the Commune People's Committee
            (PC), to be followed if needed, subsequently at the district
            PC, the provincial PC, and finally at the district peoples
            court. External monitoring and evaluation will also verify
            that complaints have been resolved appropriately in
            accordance with the RAP policy framework. Additionally, the
            project includes both internal, and external monitoring and
            evaluation measures, focusing on social impacts of the
            project, and whether the DP have improved, or at least
            maintained their living standards, income earning capacity,
            and production levels.

repnme.cdata!:
Vietnam - Road Network Improvement Project
            : resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Road Network Improvement Project
            (RNIP) for Vietnam will focus on the rehabilitation, and
            strategic widening of roadways, in the Northern provinces in
            Vietnam, thus reducing road transit times and
            vehicle-operating costs, while improving road access to
            poor, isolated agricultural communities, and facilitating
            agricultural production marketing. This resettlement action
            plan (RAP) provides the policy framework for compensation,
            resettlement and rehabilitation of displaced persons, as a
            result of project implementation, in compliance with the
            country's legal and regulatory policies, and the
            Bank's guidelines on resettlement. It is presented in 4
            volumes: the Umbrella Report (V. 1) which provides the
            general guidelines; RAP National Highway NH 37 (V. 2); RAP
            National Highway NH 47 (V. 3); and, RAP National Highway NH
            48 outlining the policy framework for each specific road
            segment. Compensation payments will be awarded at
            replacement costs, while land for land arrangements will be
            made, unless replacement land is unavailable, or, at the
            informed request of the displaced person (DP), cash
            compensation may be provided. Different subsidy allowances
            and other forms of assistance are also available to
            different categories of DP. Severely affected DP will be
            entitled to food aid, and/or training and income restoration
            programs, available through the District Agricultural
            Extension Office, and other relevant offices. Public
            consultation should enhance an active participation in the
            planning, and implementation of the RAP, being the
            responsibility of the project management unit to implement a
            public information campaign. Grievance mechanisms should be
            addressed beginning with the Commune People's Committee
            (PC), to be followed if needed, subsequently at the district
            PC, the provincial PC, and finally at the district peoples
            court. External monitoring and evaluation will also verify
            that complaints have been resolved appropriately in
            accordance with the RAP policy framework. Additionally, the
            project includes both internal, and external monitoring and
            evaluation measures, focusing on social impacts of the
            project, and whether the DP have improved, or at least
            maintained their living standards, income earning capacity,
            and production levels.
